block.p: William R. Phillips, a former New York police officer who was a star witness for a commission investigating police corruption in the 1970s, has spent the last 32 years in prison for murdering a prostitute and her pimp.
He has lost an eye to cancer and had two operations, for prostate cancer and a stroke.

William R. Phillips, a former New York police officer who was a star witness for a commission investigating police corruption in the 1970s, has spent the last 32 years in prison for murdering a prostitute and her pimp.
He has lost an eye to cancer and had two operations, for prostate cancer and a stroke.

He lost yet another battle yesterday, as -- for the second time -- the appellate division of State Supreme Court in Manhattan ruled that he did not deserve to be granted parole, reversing a lower court ruling that was scathingly critical of the parole board.

The five-judge appellate panel ruled that the release of Mr. Phillips, who is 76, would undermine respect for the law. Mr. Phillips, the court wrote in its six-page decision, had committed crimes that were a ''perversion'' of his power as a New York City police officer, and had shown ''limited remorse and insight into his criminal acts.''
''As to the seriousness of the crime, we strongly disagree with petitioner's implication that the nature of his crime was no more heinous than any other murder,'' the court said.

Mr. Phillips, a policeman for 17 years, was sentenced to 25 years to life in prison for the 1968 murders of James Smith, a pimp who, the prosecutor said, was killed for failing to make a protection payment, and Sharon Stango, a prostitute who was an eyewitness. Mr. Phillips asserted that he had been framed in retaliation for exposing police corruption.

It is the second time since 2003 that Mr. Phillips, who testified before the Knapp Commission, has gone through the same cycle of being denied parole, having a lower court reverse the parole board, and then having the appellate division reverse the lower court. The commission found that corruption was pervasive in the Police Department.
''It's very sad, very frustrating,'' his lawyer, Daniel Perez, said yesterday. ''It's like he's stuck in an endless Ping-Pong match.''
''There is something fundamentally wrong with a system in which judges keep conflicting with each other on the same case with the same person. Once you could understand, twice is bizarre.''
Mr. Perez said that this time, he would appeal the case to the Court of Appeals, the state's highest court, and that his argument would focus on the conflict between courts.
He said he was at a loss to explain that conflict. But he added: ''I know that this is a politically sensitive case. I know that Bill Phillips is not your average parole applicant.''

He said he was also distressed that the appellate division had introduced what he said was a new factor into its decision, by identifying his client's ''purported lack of remorse,'' as a reason for denying parole, when the parole board itself ''said nothing about his lack of remorse.''

The appellate division reversed a decision in October by Justice Marcy S. Friedman of State Supreme Court in Manhattan, who said that Mr. Phillips had been a model prisoner and posed no threat to society and that the parole board had, in essence, conducted its own resentencing.
Mr. Phillips was recruited by the Knapp Commission after it caught him taking payoffs from Xaviera Hollander, the madam who wrote the best seller ''The Happy Hooker.''
He contended that he was framed on murder charges by a detective who was angry about his televised testimony before the commission.
